sect1.title: Remote Admin
sect1.para: The Remote Admin tab provides control over the process and rules for administering the ⪚. It is divided into 5 sub tabs. The first, as discussed in , is used to create accounts which can administer the ⪚. The next section, covered in , is used to control access to the Administrative Console from a network level. The third tab, as seen in , is used to control the Digital Certificate used when accessing the ⪚ via Secure Sockets Layer (SSL). The fourth tab, discussed in , is used to configure industry standard monitoring protocols such as SNMP and Syslog. The final tab allows administrators to reboot their ⪚, as discussed in .

sect2.title: Admin Accounts
sect2.para: The Admin Accounts Tab, as seen in , is used to add/modify administrator accounts. Administrators are users who are able to use the Administrative Console. This is not to be confused with end-users (people who browse the web, receive email, etc) who do not need logins to the ⪚.

There are three actions one would take with the Admin Accounts Tab: adding an administrator, removing an administrator, or changing an administrator's password. Each of these actions are detailed as follows. Note that one or more of these action may be taken, but do not take effect into the Save Settings button is pushed.

listitem.para: To add an account, push the add (plus) button to the left of the panel. This adds a new (blank) row to the table. The name column is a descriptive name, such as Emma Scott or Jun Wang. The login column is a login name, such as escott or jwang.

The next two columns, set new password and confirm new password, should be populated with the new Administrator's password. Both fields need to be filled with the same password. The next field is original user's password. When adding a new user, this field is automatically populated. Do not change the default value. The past field is for the new Administrator's email address. It may be left blank.
The new account will become active once the Save Settings button is pushed.

To remove an administrator account, highlight the account (row) to be deleted then push the remove (minus) button to the left. You must then enter the account about to be deleted's password in the original user's password. The account will be removed once the Save Settings button is pushed.

To change the password for an administrative account, highlight the account (row) of the account to change. Then enter the new password into the set new password and confirm new password fields. The existing (current) password must then be entered into the original user's password field.
The password change will take effect once the Save Settings button is pushed.

sect2.title: Access
sect2.para: The Access Tab controls how Administrators may use the Administrative Console to view and change the ⪚.

sect3.title: Restrictions
sect3.para: The Restrictions tab, as seen in , lets Administrators control how the Administrative Interface can be used.

External administration is defined as someone accessing the Administrative Interface from outside the protected network. Internal administration is someone accessing the Administrative Interface from within the protected network. Someone from the DMZ is considered external.
The current external IP address can be found from the Network Settings panel. If the ⪚ is running NAT, the internal IP can be found from the NAT settings as explained in . If the system is not running NAT, then the internal IP is the same as the external IP.
We will now discuss the details of configuring the ⪚ for external and internal administration.

simplesect.para: External administration can be enabled/disabled by selecting either the Allow or Deny options within the External Remote Administration section. Note that if enabled, all administration traffic is passed over a secure (SSL) connection.

If administration from outside the protected network is enabled, Administrators can also choose to restrict administration from a select set of machines. This restriction is set by first selecting Restrict then populating the IP Address and Netmask fields.

Internal administration can be configured to require an encrypted (SSL) connection or not. To require an SSL connection, select the Disallow option under Internal Remote Administration. Note that secure remote administration is always enabled from the internal network.

sect3.title: Public Address
sect3.para: The Public Address Tab, as seen in , should only be used under special circumstances. Those circumstances involve a different address used for access from the Internet vs. the address of the external interface of the ⪚.

Although redundant, an ⪚ can be deployed behind a router or other network device which performs redirection. For example, such a device may redirect all traffic on its IP address for port 443 to the ⪚ on port 8443.

In such a scenario, the address of the ⪚ is not the address used by people on the general Internet. From outside the corporate network, an Administrator could not reach the ⪚. To address this situation, the Public Address tab should be used. Enter the IP address and port which will be used for Internet access to the ⪚.
The port which is required for external access is 443. It is permissible to use a value other than 443 as the value for port on the ⪚, but the device performing redirection should honor 443 as the external mapping.

sect2.title: Certificates
sect2.para: The Certificates Tab controls the Digital Certificate (cert) used by the ⪚ when using SSL. Without a properly installed and signed cert, users who browse to the ⪚ will receive warning messages from their browser. Note that the Administrative Console, as well as the Quarantine features use SSL for user interaction.

Although a complete discussion of Digital Certificates is beyond the scope of this document, some background and terminology are warranted. Digital Certificates are used by a web server to identify itself. For example, if you visit Amazon.com to purchase a book you are using SSL when you enter your credit card number. Two things take place as you perform this transaction. First, SSL encrypts your web session to prevent any malicious parties from intercepting your personal information. Secondly, your browser requested Amazon.com's Digital Certificate to make sure you were in fact visiting amazon.com.

This second step is called server authentication. Your browser knows that you typed www.amazon.com, and expects the web server to return a certificate which declares this is 'www.amazon.com'. Since a Digital Certificate is easy to create (you could use the ⪚ Administrative Console to create a certificate for www.amazon.com), your browser must also make sure the certificate is authentic. This is done by examining the signature on the certificate against a list of known certificate authorities.

All browsers come with a list of dozens of certificate authorities, along with information to validate when those authorities sign web server certificates. In our example with Amazon.com, the digital certificate for www.amazon.com is signed by a Certificate Authority named Verisign. When Amazon presented its certificate to your browser, your browser went through the following steps:
Visited a web site with the address www.amazon.com and requested its digital certificate.
Examined the returned certificate and found that it claimed to be for a site called www.amazon.com. If the address you entered into your browser did not match the name of the certificate, the browser would have issued a warning that the name of the certificate does not match the visited site.
Found that this certificate was signed by an authority called Verisign. The browser then went through its list of pre installed Certificate Authorities and found and entry for Verisign. Otherwise, the browser would have issued a warning that the certificate was signed by an unknown authority.
Verified the signature on Amazon's certificate was in fact the signature of Verisign. Otherwise, the browser would have issued a warning that the signature was invalid.

Unlike the steps listed above with Amazon, a new ⪚ installation will cause the browser to issue warnings. This is due to the fact that the Digital Certificate used by the ⪚ is not signed by a known Certificate Authority. The initial (default) certificate is in fact a self-signed certificate (which is equivalent to not signed by anyone known to the browser).

To prevent browser warnings, two things are required. First is that the name of the ⪚ must be known to the Internet. This is called the hostname of the machine, configuration of which is discussed in .

The second required step is to obtain a cert from a well-known certificate authority. There are many certificate authorities which charge varying fees for a digital certificate. Examples of popular certificate authorities include Verisign and Thwate.

To obtain a valid, signed certificate from a certificate authority, the following steps must be followed.
A self-signed certificate must be created (see ). This certificate includes not only the name of the ⪚ machine, but information about the owning organization (name, location, etc). The initial self-signed certificate created by a new ⪚ deployment lacks much of this information.
A Certificate Signature Request (CSR) must be created (see ). This is a standard digital document accepted by all certificate authorities as the initial step in the process of obtaining a digital certificate.
The CSR must be presented to a certificate authority along with any payments for the signature service. The certificate authority may also request additional information to verify that you own the web site for-which you are requesting the certificate.
After performing verifications, the certificate authority returns a signed digital certificate for your ⪚. This certificate can then be installed (imported) into the ⪚, as discussed in .

sect3.title: Status
sect3.para: The Status Tab, as seen in , displays information about the currently installed Digital Certificate.

The status screen displays information such as the lifetime and Distinguished Name (DN) of the certificate. Note that the initial certificate for a ⪚ lacks much information (and should be replaced, as discussed in ).

sect3.title: Generation
sect3.para: The Generation Tab contains buttons to follow the required steps to obtain a working digital certificate for an ⪚: creating a self-signed certificate, generating a certificate signature request, and importing the signed certificate into the ⪚.

sect4.title: Generate Self Signed Certificate
sect4.para: The Generate Self Signed Certificate Window, as seen in , is used by Administrators to generate a new self-signed digital certificate..
All information on this form must be filled-in, except the Hostname which is automatically obtained from the hostname of the ⪚ (see ).

sect4.title: Generate Certificate Signature Request
sect4.para: The Generate Certificate Signature Request (CSR) Window, as seen in , will produce a CSR based on the current certificate information (see );

To use, push the proceed button as seen in . This will fill-in the window with several lines of text starting with -----BEGIN NEW CERTIFICATE REQUEST-----. You should cut and paste this text into the form provided by your certificate authority.
Many certificate authorities offer different types of certificates. For the ⪚, an "SSL" or "Web Server" certificate should be purchased.

sect4.title: Import Signed Certificate
sect4.para: The Import Signed Certificate Window, as seen in is used to enter the signed certificate returned from the certificate authority.

The certificate itself will either be emailed or received in a web browser. Like the process of creating the CSR, importing the certificate requires one to cut-and-paste text into a window (as shown in ).

Some CAs may also return a second intermediate certificate. If your CA has provided such a certificate, it may be pasted into the bottom window as seen in .
If there is no intermediate certificate provided by your CA, this field may be left blank.

sect2.title: Monitoring
sect2.para: The Monitoring Tab lets the Administrator configure SNMP (see as well as Syslog (as discussed in ) support.

sect3.title: SNMP Monitoring
sect3.para: The SNMP Monitoring tab, as seen in , controls how the ⪚ uses SNMP.

The ⪚ is able to respond to read-only SNMP queries. It exports MIB-II (see RFC 1213), as well as (optionally) sends traps. To enable the ⪚ to field SNMP queries, select the Enable SNMP Monitoring option as seen in .

If Enable SNMP Monitoring is selected, three additional pieces of information should be provided. The first is the Community, which is used in SNMP v1 to authenticate queries.
Be sure to change the default community value when enabling this feature
The next two fields are System Contact and System Location. Although not required for normal operation, they greatly assist in troubleshooting. They should be populated with contact information and the physical location of the ⪚ (respectively).

The ⪚ can also be configured to send warm and cold start traps. To enable the sending of traps, select Enable Traps at the bottom of the SNMP Monitoring tab. You must then provide a host/port (via the Host and Port respectively). The field Community must be populated with the community string for the trap-receiving server.
Not all SNMP trap receiver tools require a community string. If your tool does not require a community string, the Community field can be left blank.

sect3.title: Syslog Monitoring
sect3.para: Syslog Monitoring, as seen in , allows Administrators to redirect information from the ⪚ to a Syslog server.

From the Syslog Monitoring tab, Administrators can enable/disable their ⪚ from sending Syslog messages via selecting either Disable Syslog Monitoring or Enable Syslog Monitoring. If Enable Syslog Monitoring is selected, further information is required for this feature to function.

The Host field is the name of the server running a Syslog server. This server should be configured to allow remote submission of Syslog messages. The next field is Port, and should only be changed from the standard port (512) should the Syslog server be listening on a non-standard port.

Facility is the Syslog facility for which the ⪚ messages will be submitted. The Facility contains all standard Syslog values for facility. Threshold is the minimum Syslog threshold, such that ⪚ will not send messages below this level. Note that ⪚ sends messages at the informational, notice and warning levels. In general, messages indicating traffic was inspected and found not to contain questionable content is sent as informational. Inspected traffic which required ⪚ to take action (for example, blocking a restricted web page) is sent as notice. The exception to this last case is for viruses found, which are sent as warning messages.

sect2.title: Manual Reboot
sect2.para: The Manual Reboot Tab, as seen in , provides the ability for Administrators to reboot their ⪚ system without physical access to the machine.
To reboot, push the Reboot EdgeGuard button.
